BE11:21am

STAFFLINE GROUP PLC

("Staffline" or "the Group")

Company Update

Further to this morning's announcement, the Company can confirm that this morning concerns were brought to the attention of the Board relating to invoicing and payroll practices within the Recruitment division.

Given the nature of the allegations, the preliminary results will not be published until the matters have been fully investigated. The Board is confident that its policies in relation to these matters are appropriate, particularly given that these practices have been the subject of prior audits. However, if the allegations are substantiated this could have a material impact on the Group and its profitability and until further investigation has been undertaken the Board cannot assess the potential materiality.

Other than that noted above, the financial position of the Company is unchanged, as reported on 8 January the Company expects to report net debt of c£63m for the year ended 31 December 2018 and can also report that in July 2018 the Company refinanced its £150m lending facilities.

Pending further investigation of these matters, including the impact on the Company's profitability and existing forecasts, the Company has requested suspension of the Company's shares from trading on AIM and shareholders will be updated in due course.

It's a miss on sales.

11:27 am

And a beat on margins.

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,913, down 153 (-3.76%), High: 4,034, Low: 3,905, Volume: 1.30m
BE11:28am

Here's UBS.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Unilever’s Q4 underlying sales growth (USG) of +2.9% missed consensus forecasts at +3.5% due to weak volumes (+0.8% vs cons +1.5%). However, FY18 U/L EBIT margin at 18.4% beat (cons: 18.2%), and FY18 EPS at €2.36 was +2% ahead (in part helped by below-the-line items as EBIT was +0.7% ahead). Despite the EPS beat, we expect a muted share price reaction today – we think Unilever’s FY19 guidance (see below) and a lack of new buybacks leave little room for consensus earnings upgrades. The third straight year of USG deterioration (despite various growth initiatives and 27 acquisitions since 2015) suggests that Unilever’s focus on profitability is having undesirable results on its top line. This is disappointing, and might de-rate the shares. The new CEO has noted in the press release that accelerating growth will be his “number one priority”. Delivering on this promise might require more investment, in our view.

BE11:28am

What is the 2019 guidance and how does it compare to consensus?
Unilever is guiding for USG at the lower half of its long-term 3-5% range, with continued margin expansion. Unilever said it remains on track for its 2020 goals. We find the 2019 USG guidance disappointing: M&A and the Spreads disposal should have added more than 1% point growth to Unilever’s USG by now. Consensus forecasts of +3.9% USG and 19.0% EBIT margin do not leave too much room for upgrades, in our view
Valuation: 18x 2020E P/E looks fair; limited room for re-rating
At 18x 20E P/E Unilever trades broadly in line with its EU Staples peers. We think the current USG weakness makes it difficult to justify a re-rating. We stay Neutral.

BE11:29am

And Investec.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

FY18 growth of 3.1% ex Spreads is in line with consensus, with some shift to price-led growth in Q4, as flagged by the
company. For the full year, volume rose 2.1% and price 1.0% – again in line with consensus. Optically, Q418 growth of 2.9%
missed the 3.5% consensus but, given a FY18 in line, this simply reflects mathematical quirks in the consensus gathering in
our view. Argentina hyperinflation accounting cut reported growth by 50bps. A strong 80bps margin improvement in FY18
was ahead of the 70bps expectation and drove EPS of €2.36, 2% ahead of €2.31 consensus. Margin performance was
boosted by a 10bp reduction in marketing spend, which denoted greater efficiency of spend using digital platforms, rather
than any inherent pull-back in brand support, in our view. Implied FY19 guidance for top line growth of 3-4% compares with
current consensus +3.8%, while reaffirmation of the 20% margin by 2020 goal is very reassuring.

saga RPC / Berry?!?!?!
BE11:30am

Unilever trades on 18.6x our FY19E EPS – a 10% discount to Nestle – with the shares yielding 3.7% (FY19E), at the upper
end of the sector ex Tobacco. Continuing strong cost control and management’s confidence in attaining its 20% margin by
2020 goal is reassuring, while FY19 growth should be supported by the inclusion of several niche brands entering the organic
calculation, and the lapping during H219 of Argentina hyperinflation accounting. Longer term, we continue to see M&A
optionality and regard Unilever as offering defensive growth at a reasonable price. Our Buy recommendation and target price
are unchanged. We expect immaterial changes to consensus expectations for FY19.

BE11:30am

And, I dunno, Liberum?

11:30 am
BE11:31am

We rate Unilever hold with a €49.6 GBp 4,350 target price. In our view, the risk reward outlook for the shares is balanced. Management is reinvesting 2/3rds of a €6bn cost savings program in growth initiatives and is committed to delivering an ambitious 20% underlying EBIT margin target by 2020. Unilever also remains focused on shareholder returns - the dividend is growing 8% in 2018 and the group returned €xxbn via a share buyback in 2018. While more aggressive EPS growth certainly underpins the shares, failure to deliver on lifted expectations could lead to a pull-back. In addition, the company’s bold margin targets could be unsustainable in the long run. Over 2018- 2020E, we expect Unilever to deliver ~4% organic sales CAGR and a 20% underlying EBIT margin, in-line with management expectations.

Valuation at 18.5x cal’19E PE

Unilever currently trades on a 18.5x cal’19E PE, an 8% premium to the European Consumer Staples sector, with the valuation reflecting the aggressive EPS assumptions in line with the ambitious 2020 targets. The shares offer a cal’19E FCF yield of 4.4% below the 5.2% long-run avg. The cal’19E dividend yield of 3.5% likely reflects the fair value that the shares offer.

VV75 any more grey on Metro Bank, the stock keeps plummeting?

BE11:34am

Metro Bank was forced to come clean about an accounting error after it was discovered by regulators – not by the bank's own staff, as its chief executive had claimed.

The lender last week admitted it underestimated the risk in a string of commercial and buy-to-let property loans, a mistake which could force it to raise another £300million from investors.

Boss Craig Donaldson said the problem was flagged up by an internal review, after an auditor checked its books late last year.

But the Mail can reveal that the error, which sent shares crashing 39 per cent, was in fact first identified by the Prudential Regulation Authority arm of the Bank of England responsible for overseeing the health of major lenders.

BE11:41am

Post the Aug-18 rate hike, lenders have been able to maintain deposit pricing
discipline, with market avg deposit rates in both retail and commercial lines moving
only modestly. Retail sight deposits ended the year with Dec-18 at 0.51% & Q4'18
at 0.49%, and time deposits at Dec-18 at 0.72% & Q4'18 at 0.72% - see exhibit 2.
Commercial deposits tell a similar story with sight deposits in Dec-18 at 0.41% &
Q4'18 at 0.40%, and time deposits at Dec-18 at 0.72% & Q4'18 at 0.71% - see exhibit 4.
Lacklustre 2018 deposit growth recovers in Dec-18, with YoY% growth at 2.22% and
QoQ% growth at 1.1%
Corporate deposits grew 1.2% MoM Dec-18, bringing Q4'18 growth to 2.3%, and
ending 2018 with YoY% growth of 5.9%. Dec-18 still falls below the 2018 average
monthly YoY% growth of 6.93% - see exhibit 1.
Decelerating retail deposit growth stabilised in H2'18
The deceleration in retail deposit growth rates from Sep-16 highs appears to have
stabilised in H2'18 with Dec-18 bringing Q4'18 growth to 0.9% and rounding out 2018
with YoY growth of 2.6%

Blackbag99 @excel. shhh, just keep clipping coupons
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Declining lending growth pauses on commercial lending growth (PNFCs 2018 YoY:
11.7%)
2018 has been a tumultuous year for commercial lending growth, distorted by
opposite lending behavior between PNFCs and lending to non-bank financials.
Corporate lending shrank 0.7% in Q4'18; however, this is off the back of strong Q2'18
growth (12.4%), which drove YoY growth of 11% - see exhibit 1.
Consumer credit growth continues to wane shrinking 0.02% in Q4'18
Consumer credit continued its two-year deceleration, with 2018 growth of 1.32%,
driven by increases in repayments outstripping increasing consumer credit
borrowings - see exhibit 7. This growth rate is likely due to regulatory scrutiny of noncard
unsecured balances.
By product, credit card growth (42% of consumer credit) continued its decline,
with 2018 growth at 1.29% (2017: 3.85%). Personal loans (51% of consumer credit)
similarly decelerated to 2018 growth of 1.61% (2017: 2.96%).

BE11:42am

That's all a bit lumpy. Here's the summary.

BE11:42am

With pressures of slowing loan growth and squeezes on prices, Q4'18 looks to have been a difficult quarter. However, it is not all negative news: post the BoE rate hike, lenders have been able to shift the cost of deposits further towards customers, allowing them to support NIMs in light of pressures on pricing. We can expect Lloyds (Buy) to be able to continue its strong NIM performance on the back of this, in addition to its structural hedge preserving NIMs from the pricing side.

My understanding of takeover law means that while it can't bump due to that statement, if another party submits a formal offer there's a whitewash. This may be wrong though. If any arbs want to correct me they know my email.

BE11:48am

The possibility of a Berry-RPC deal has been talked about for some time but the idea was usually that the US group was distracted by previous deals and a bit risk averse.

BE11:48am

Perhaps having Apollo doing the DD to conclusion has given them confidence to gazump. Here's Cazenove:

11:48 am
BE11:48am

A merger of RPC and Berry would create a global powerhouse in plastic
packaging with a combined revenue base that we estimate would be the largest in the world on a pro forma trailing basis.

BE11:49am

A global powerhouse in plastic packaging. Imagine.

BE11:49am

No offer value indicated by synergies may help. Berry has not indicated what it might offer for RPC if it does proceed to bid for the company. As a strategic buyer, however, it would expect to generate operating synergies from acquiring RPC and this may help justify a higher price than that put on the table by Apollo. The usual quantum of operating syenrgies in plastic packaging transactions is 4-5% of acquired revenue, which would imply £150-190 million, or 37-46p per share. For comparison, indicative synergies in the recent acquisition of Bemis by Amcor were equal to 4.4% of acquired revenue.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Berry -- previously owned by Apollo, oddly -- is already ND/EBITDA of 4x at the end of the last financial year so doesn't have a lot of room to get into a bidding war.

Blackbag99 Italian debt is just free money. Target balances are not risk, they are just architecture never to be repaid.
BE11:50am

Here's Numis:

BE11:51am

US-listed peer, Berry is a major producer of non-woven, and both
rigid and flexible packaging products, to consumer and industrial end market. For the year to end September 2018 the company generated net sales of $7.9bn (+11% yoy), EBITDA of $1,380m (+4% yoy), and adj. EPS of $3.37 (+10%). With year-end net debt of c.$5.5bn, period end net debt/EBITDA was 3.9x, or 3.8x based on anticipated synergies from acquisitions.
● Valuation offers scope for enhanced offer. The recent recommended final offer for RPC Group from Apollo Capital Management valued the company on March 2019 P/E and EV/EBITDA multiples of 10.7x and 7.3x, respectively. We consider this offer to be low relative to international peer group valuations. Given the scope for synergies, an offer from an industry participant such as Berry, at a premium to current valuation could be justified, offering scope for an enhanced offer for shareholders.

BE11:59am

Q4 clean net income came in at USD5.7bn (+32% YOY, and +1% QOQ) c.
USD0.4bn or 6% above our estimates (KECH USD5.34bn, consensus
USD5.28bn). The beat came from the refining segment (see table below).
Operating cash flow (ex. WCR, pre-interest) was USD12.9bn (KECH
USD11.59bn), 11% above our estimates, helped by a USD1.62bn positive
impact from derivatives (including the margin call on hedging
derivatives). Stripping out that item, underlying cash flow (ex WCR) was
USD11.3bn, broadly in line with our estimates. CFFO (pre-interests) was
stellar at USD22bn, benefitting from a massive WCR of USD9.1bn (due to
the fall in oil prices), but a reassuring feature after the adverse WC
outflow over the last 12 months.

BE11:59am

Capital investment was USD8bn in Q4
2018 and USD24.7bn over FY 2018 (in line with guidance). On buy-backs,
Shell announced the third tranche of USD2.5bn. The reserves
replacement ratio was poor at c. 53% (as expected, as despite the LNG
Canada FID, few reserves would be booked on that project). Shell
confirmed that the 2019 capex guidance will stay firmly within the
USD25-30bn range; an outcome at the lower end would be welcome but
that was not specified in the press release.

Blackbag99 You have to assume that Italy would pay back at exchange mechanism rates, legally binding rate. And the currency would be worth significantly lower than that rate. So Germany takes a haircut

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Here's Citi.

Baru Cheers BE
Blackbag99 A haircut at torso level
BE12:00pm

Central to the RDS investment proposition is prioritisation of
shareholders, through a combination of a high dividend payout and a buyback programme. However the debate, in our view, is at what cost? It is clear that the financial framework to support this is finely balanced: dividends have been flat now for 20 quarters and are unlikely to rise, while the ongoing struggles around reservelife relative to peers suggest there is limited capacity for real growth in the business. Flat dividends and limited growth is hardly enticing in a world of rising rates. Sell.

BE12:01pm

Is RDS enticing versus the market? Against a 2018 delivery of
12.4% ROE, and expectations that returns can expand a little more, the current valuation of 1.4x book looks inexpensive. But that value-framework is also true of many other Integrated Oils in Europe. A key difference between RDS and peers lies in reserve-life, which at 8.5 years (down from 8.8 years end-17) is 30% below the peer average. Some criticize the SEC reserve metric, but we see it as the only tangible, audited metric that investors have to judge the robustness of future growth. 30% less visibility than peers, in our view, deserves a valuation discount to peers.
